isis.stitle: VT-365 Diesel Engine Diagnostics (2002) - ENGINE SYMPTOMS DIAGNOSTICS - Test Procedures - Smoke

item.para: Turbocharger failure, turbocharger blade damage or turbocharger wheel stuck
Altitude (black smoke on hard acceleration or snap acceleration may be pronounced at higher elevations)

step1.para: If engine has fuel knock or there is evidence of fuel in the exhaust, remove exhaust manifolds and inspect for fuel in the exhaust ports. (Suspect loose injectors, missing or damaged O-ring and gasket on bottom of injector).
Inspect air inlet system and exhaust system for possible sources of restriction.
Visually inspect turbocharger for oil leakage or failure of blades. Some oil carryover is expected due to the closed crankcase ventilation system.
Do Test 9 (Intake Restriction) on Performance Diagnostics form EGED-250 or in Section 6 of this manual.
Do Test 11 (Exhaust Restriction) on form EGED-250 or in Section 6 of this manual.

item.para: Coolant leak to combustion from exhaust side

step1.para: In cold ambient temperatures, some white smoke is normal until the engine is up to operating temperature.

item.para: Ensure that engine is up to operating temperature 88°C (190°F) prior to verifying a white smoke complaint.
If the engine is unable to obtain operating temperature during a road test, verify thermostat opening temperature 88°C (190°F).

step1.para: On a cold engine, the glow plug system may remain on for up to two minutes after the engine starts to assist in cold smoke cleanup. Do Tests 15A and 15B (Glow Plug System) on Hard Start and No Start Diagnostics form EGED-245 to verify glow plug operation.

Do Test 2 (Fuel) on Performance Diagnostics form EGED-250. Verify quality and quantity of diesel fuel. Poor quality fuel or low cetane rating can cause white smoking, engine misfire and low power. Refer to the Engine Operation and Maintenance Manual, Fuel Requirements section for model and year of engine to determine minimum necessary fuel grade and cetane rating.
Do Test 10 (EGR Position) on Performance Diagnostics form EGED-250 if operator complaint is white smoke on start-up only. Do test according to condition of operator complaint.
If there is coolant loss without engine overheating, check for coolant in exhaust.

item.para: If coolant is leaking from exhaust or can be smelled in the exhaust, refer to Coolant Leak to Exhaust diagnostics in this section.

step1.para: If engine has fuel knock or evidence of fuel in exhaust, remove exhaust manifolds and inspect for fuel in the exhaust ports. (Suspect loose injectors, missing or damaged O-ring and copper gasket on bottom of injector).
Inspect air induction system for evidence of water ingestion or evidence of unfiltered air entering the engine.

item.para: Water ingestion could have caused a hydraulic lock and bent connecting rods. If water ingestion is suspected, identify smoking cylinders by removing exhaust manifolds and running engine.

Unfiltered air entering the engine can cause excessive power cylinder wear and turbocharger compressor blade damage. If power cylinder wear is suspected, identify smoking cylinder(s) by removing exhaust manifolds and running engine.
If coolant is found in the intake manifold, refer to Coolant Leak to Exhaust diagnostics in this section.

step1.para: Do compression test on cylinders that are white smoking using the compression test adapter. Inspect turbocharger for damage.

If engine is overheating with coolant loss, and cylinder head gasket, injector sleeve or glow plug sleeve is suspected for leaking, refer to Combustion Leaks to Coolant Test using High Pressure in this section.

item.para: Leaking valve stem seals or worn valve guides

step1.para: Do oil consumption test on engine. Verify high oil consumption.
Do Test 17 (Crankcase Pressure) on Performance Diagnostics form EGED-250 or Section 6 of this manual.

item.para: If crankcase pressure is high and there is excessive oil consumption, investigate air compressor, turbocharger, and power cylinder components.
If crankcase pressure is normal and there is excessive oil consumption continue with next step.

step1.para: Remove Charge Air Cooler (CAC) pipes and inspect CAC and intake system for excessive oil carryover.

note.para: Oil in the air induction system is normal, since the engine has a closed breather.

step1.para: Inspect turbocharger for oil leak at both the compressor and turbine housings.
Remove exhaust manifolds and inspect exhaust ports for oil residue to pinpoint possible injector failure causing oil to mix with fuel injected into the power cylinder.

item.para: If crankcase pressure is normal and oil consumption is more than one quart per 500 miles, replace fuel injector in cylinder where oil residue is identified.
